adr_address: 5 Rue de Dunkerque, 75010 Paris, France

editorial_summary.overview: Buzzy lodging with low-key dorms & rooms, plus a bar/restaurant & complimentary breakfast.

name: St Christopher's Inn Paris - Gare du Nord

reviews.text:
Bad hostel. The room has bad smell, and the basic stuff is broken. All the men on the first floor have to shall the only two shower head. Hair dryer is required to be borrowed from the desk. The internet is soooooo slow that you can never download any app with it. Considering its price is not low, it is my worst experience of youth hostel in Europe.

Edit: Damn, it is even difficult to listen to music with the slow internet! Even the internet in 2001 can be better than this :/

Edit after three days: it seems the bad smell came from a roommate but not the room. The smell went away after he left..

I found a cockroach larvae or bed bug during my stay. I also have a bug bite, and the door closed properly half the time.
Otherwise, the staff was friendly and efficient, they had socials every night and were in a convenient location.
But would not recommend to anyone, the room was so hot it interestingly smelt like sweat.

I only stayed for one night but stayed in a 10 bed female dorm and was great. Beds were clean and comfy, the curtains add a lot of privacy. A bit loud with the windows open so bring earplugs. There’s plug sockets and lights above the bed and a locker underneath to store your things (bring your own lock or buy one at reception for €2). The reception staff were super lovely and they have lockers downstairs for luggage storage outside of your booking. The location is quite central and easy to get to tourist attractions, however felt a little bit unsafe at night so I went to the bar attached in the evening (and I was also exhausted), and the bar staff were also super friendly. People in my room went out however so must be okay. All around good experience.

Quite frankly, I wish this hostel had been fully booked *before* I reserved a bed because this place was easily the worst hostel of my month long trip across Europe.

The scale of the place is hard to describe, but the bar whose patrons occlude the reception area, make the place seem overrun. The morning after I arrived (Tuesday/Wednesday), not a single extra bed was free, which is an uncomfortable thought if one takes issue with their room in particular.

There is one ladder shared by two sets of bunk beds and requires some dexterity as it is anchored at a 90 degree angle to the beds itself. The top bunks are open to the ceiling, which, if you're light sensitive without an eye mask, means every flick of the light becomes a problem. I woke up instantly when the first guest left in the morning, after specifically searching for a hostel with a capsule/pod-like bed to avoid this.

The size of the room itself becomes an issue when the underbed storage isn't accessible because the caged lid won't open until it's fully withdrawn. The entire walkway becomes occluded, also meaning the front door won't open if someone has their drawer open. The likelihood of this becoming an issue at certain times of the day is highly probable.

There's a sink and mirror in the room, but given the lack of respect I experienced from other guests in the space, I imagine this could become a source of contention for some. I did notice the bathrooms were filthy on my floor and there was a stark lack of check marks after 11:00, indicating an employee had come around to clean things. I used the facilities as late as 23:00 and noticed the next morning that someone had added extra check marks where there were none. There had been a sink full of crud all day, where it seemed someone washed mud caked socks, and another sink had a contact lens in it that would rehydrate anytime someone used the sink. It's nice that the showers have a locking door and places to put toiletries, but they share a divider with a toilet stall and the motion lights go out on you while showering and the water button must be pressed every 15 or 20 seconds.

I found the place entirely lacking in common areas that aren't an obnoxious bar. The location is prime for other nightlife, but for folks hoping for some quiet solitude to work on their laptops, this place is not it.

You have to buy locks and towels (no deposit system).

This would be my last resort hostel every time. While it can be fairly cheap (~40€), it still feels like quite a rip off, given how lovely my stay was at hostels in Belgium and Berlin. I'd choose anywhere else.

I stayed for 2 nights. It was about 25C high the days I stayed and it was not too hot. There was music at night but I was able to sleep. Everything was good, the showers, the bed, the hostel in general. The location was amazing as I was arriving and leaving by train at Gare du Nord. The only thing I found that was annoying was you had to pay €7/€8 to store your bag on your last day of you are leaving later.
